G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: Defendant Mark Thompson is an individual who, upon information and belief, owns, operates, manages, and/or controls the residential rental property located at 15 Mystic Street, Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts 02150 (the “Premises”), and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea Division of the District Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea Division of the District Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building at 15 Mystic Street, including but not limited to the main entry door, hallways, and basement, in a condition that is safe, secure, and compliant with Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building at 15 Mystic Street, including but not limited to the main entry door, hallways, and basement, in a condition that is safe, secure, and compliant with Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.

105 CMR 410.750; 105 CMR 410.351 & 410.7.proposition: The defective and unsecured condition of the Main Entry Door also constitutes a violation of the State Sanitary Code requirement that the owner maintain the building and its facilities in good repair and in a safe condition for occupants. See 105 CMR 410.750; 105 CMR 410.351 & 410.750 (obligation to maintain structural elements and facilities).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: The defective and unsecured condition of the Main Entry Door further constitutes a condition that materially impairs the health, safety, and wellbeing of tenants within the meaning of G.L. c. 111, § 127A and related provisions concerning the enforcement of the State Sanitary Code.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects a tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the “tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment” in a residential setting and holds that substantial interference with that enjoyment—here, loud nighttime bar noise attributable to the landlord—constitutes a breach and constructive eviction. The court explains that a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when, as a natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts, omissions, or permitted activities, tenants are very substantially deprived of the use and enjoyment of their premises. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenancies contain an implied covenant protecting tenants from substantial interference by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when a landlord’s acts or omissions have the natural and probable consequence of interfering substantially with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the standard for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and expressly adopts the “natural and probable consequence” formulation, citing prior Massachusetts cases. The court explains that modern decisions impose liability under the covenant when the landlord’s acts or omissions have the natural and probable consequence of interrupting the tenant’s rights, which is substantively the same as substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. Thus the case directly supports the stated proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott… Shindler v. Milden….”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where, after receiving notice, the landlord unreasonably fails to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions, or conditions that impair the security, privacy, and habitability of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment by omitting reasonable measures to address serious, known conditions (here, pervasive drug activity) that substantially interfere with tenants’ use of the premises. The opinion explains that a breach can arise from what the landlord ‘failed to do’ or ‘permitted to be done’ and applies that to security, privacy, and habitability interests in common areas, contingent on notice and unreasonable inaction. This aligns with the proposition that landlords may be liable when, after notice, they unreasonably fail to correct unsafe or unsanitary conditions or conditions impairing security, privacy, and habitability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 does not require proof of malice; it is sufficient that the landlord intentionally engaged in the acts or omissions that caused the interference, and that the resulting interference was a natural and probable consequence of those acts or omissions.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the need to prove intent to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, emphasizing that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling. It further adopts the "natural and probable consequence" standard, citing Simon v. Solomon and Westland Housing, thereby aligning with the proposition that liability is based on intentional acts/omissions whose natural and probable consequence is interference, without requiring malice. The court also notes it is unnecessary to consider whether the failure to provide heat was intentional in the sense of specific wrongful purpose.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather “the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.” Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself (see Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99-100 [1982]), liability will be imposed “whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.” Id. at 102, quoting from Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 does not require proof of malice; it is sufficient that the landlord intentionally engaged in the acts or omissions that caused the interference, and that the resulting interference was a natural and probable consequence of those acts or omissions.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects strict liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and instead requires at least negligent conduct, including notice or reason to know of the condition. It does say that liability arises when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action is interference, but it ties that to fault (negligence or recklessness), not merely to intentional acts or omissions without malice. Thus it does not support the proposition that proof of malice is unnecessary and that mere intentional acts causing foreseeable interference suffice regardless of fault level.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures. … We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to remedy known conditions that substantially impair a tenant’s safety, security, or habitability can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–05 (landlord’s failure to correct flooding conditions after notice); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994) (conditions violating sanitary code can support quiet enjoyment claim); Doe, 417 Mass. at 284–85 (failure to take reasonable protective measures after notice of dangerous conditions).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to correct known sanitary, building, and fire code violations that substantially impair the value of the premises constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). The court emphasizes that omissions such as failure to repair defects after notice can breach quiet enjoyment and applies that principle to conditions including inadequate heat and hot water and vermin infestation. This directly supports the proposition that failure to take reasonable steps to remedy known conditions impairing safety, security, or habitability can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. See Simon v. Solomon… (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko… (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas… (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so). … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 144 Vt. 150, 157\u2.proposition: Violations of the Sanitary Code that substantially impair health or safety can support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Cruz Mgmt., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Hilder v. St. Peter, 144 Vt. 150, 157–58 (1984) (persuasive authority cited by Massachusetts courts regarding habitability and quiet enjoyment).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 144 Vt. 150, 157\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about recognizing and defining an implied warranty of habitability and related remedies in residential leases. It does reference sanitary and housing code violations as prima facie evidence of breach of the implied warranty, but it does not discuss or apply any doctrine of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it links substantial code-related health and safety violations to habitability, it does not support the specific proposition that such violations can support a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 144 Vt. 150, 157\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether there has been a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, the courts may first look to any relevant local or municipal housing code… A substantial violation of an applicable housing code shall constitute prima facie evidence that there has been a breach of the warranty of habitability. ‘[O]ne or two minor violations standing alone which do not affect the health or safety of the tenant, shall be considered de minimus and not a breach of the warranty.’” (144 Vt. at 160–61).

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also reflects a disregard for Plaintiff’s rights protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14, justifying the statutory remedy of at least three months’ rent. See Lowery, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983–84 (quiet enjoyment damages are mandatory upon a finding of violation); Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400–01 (1982) (statutory remedies designed to deter landlord misconduct).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.support_reasoning: Wolfberg discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 only to address whether a tenant may recover both c. 93A damages and the separate ‘three months’ rent’ statutory remedy, and it holds that such recovery would be duplicative when the tenant already received more than three months’ rent and actual damages under c. 93A. The opinion does not describe the § 14 remedy as being ‘designed to deter landlord misconduct’ in any general policy sense; rather, it characterizes the triple-rent clause narrowly as an incentive when actual damages are slight or hard to prove. Thus the case does not squarely support the broad deterrence proposition for which it is cited.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment… The ‘triple rent’ clause of G. L. c. 186, § 14, is ‘an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove.’… We now hold that, where a tenant has been awarded in excess of both three months’ rent and actual damages under G. L. c. 93A… the recovery of damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, would be duplicative and, therefore, will not be allowed.”
